System - System control

  • Examples

  • Thread-safe Data Structure
  • References

  1. Introduction

    Thread lifecycle

    
                                    --------<--Waiting <-------------
                                    |                                  |
                                    |                        [call wait(), join()]
                                   \/                                  |
    New -> [call start()] -> Runnable (ready) -> [call run()] -> Running -> [interal return] -> terminated
                                   /\                                 |
                                    |                                 \/
                                    |                        [lock, I/O block]
                                    |                                 |
                                    --------<--Blocked <---------------

    Waiting: The thread is passively waiting for other thread to notify it.

    Blocked: The thread is actively trying to get a lock that is not available.

    Priority

    Each java thread has a priority, from Thread.MIN_PRIORITY (1) to Thread.MAX_PRIORITY (10). The default priority is Thread.NORM_PRIORITY (5).

    Different from C pthread

    1. Java main thread return, the sub-threads continue to run.

    Function

    1. Thread.currentThread(): return a Thread object (handle) that represents the current running thread.
    2. thread.set/getName(String)
    3. thread.set/getPriority(int)

  2. Examples

    1. Create threads

      i. Extends Thread

      Thread class implements the Runnable interface's run, but do nothing. So subclasses should override the Thread's run method to do tasks.

      public class CreateThread extends Thread{

    @Override
    public void run(){
        System.out.println("Sub thread");
    }
    public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {
        Thread x = new CreateThread();
        System.out.println("Start");
        x.start();
        // x.join();
        System.out.println("End");
    }
}

======== Output ========
Start
End
Sub thread

      ii. Implement Runnable

      Runnable is an interface that defines a run() function.

      public class CreateThread2 implements Runnable{
    @Override
    public void run(){
        System.out.println("SubThread");
    }
    public static void main(String [] args){
        Runnable job = new CreateThread2();
        Thread t = new Thread(job);
        t.start();
        System.out.println("Main end");
    }
}
====== Output ======
Main end
SubThread

      Internally, the two ways are same.

      start() vs. run()

      start() put the thread into a runnable state, and then the thread can invoke the run() method to run it.

      If we directly call the Runnable'run() method in the main thread, it just runs the method directly. The thread class is used to create a seperate thread, and call the run() method.

      run method是留个thread调用的,　不是留给developer调用

      iii. implement runnable by anonymous class

      public class CreateThread3 {
    public static void main(String [] args){
        new Thread(new Runnable() {
            @Override
            public void run() {
                System.out.println("New Thread by anonymous class");
            }
        }).start();
    }
}

      iv. implement runnable with lambda since Java 8

      public class CreateThread4 {
    public static void main(String [] args){
        Thread t = new Thread(()-> System.out.println("Lambda"));
        t.start();
    }
}

    2. Priority

      If two thread has different priorities, the two threads are still running interleaving instead of the low priority thread waits until the high priority thread finished.

      public class Priority extends Thread{
    private String threadName;
    public Priority(String name){
        threadName = name;
    }
    @Override
    public void run(){
        int i = 0;
        while(true) {
            i ++;
            System.out.println("sub thread:" + threadName + " " + i + ";My priority: " + Thread.currentThread().getPriority());
        }
    }
    public static void main(String [] args){
        Thread t1 = new Priority("high");
        t1.setPriority(Thread.MAX_PRIORITY);
        Thread t2 = new Priority("low");
        t2.setPriority(Thread.MIN_PRIORITY);

        t1.start();
        t2.start();
        int i = 0;
        // Thread.currentThread().setPriority(Thread.MIN_PRIORITY);
        while(true){
            //i++;
           // System.out.println("main" + i);
        }
    }
}
